ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course taught me how to approach real world phenomenon using statistical mechanics, and I learned how to write code for simulations
How to apply statistical mechanics in python.
more real world examples of statistical concepts of quantum mechanics
Computational skills related to statistical mechanics simulations and analyses

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The professor tailored the content to the topics that the students wanted to learn in order to make the class more engaging
There was little to no productive lectures, they followed no order, and had to flow.
more structured, problem sets that reinforce material
I really loved the final project, but as a I mentioned before the content was a little too random for me

Assignments are challenging but engaging, so you learn a lot after completing them. It would be nice if the instructions and requirements for each assignment could be specified more clearly on Canvas at the time that it is given.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It depends still on what they are learning and the relatability of the concepts to their research. Towards the end, I began to see how it might fit in to my research of catalysts, but it took a long time and there was a steep learning curve necessary to get there.
Only if you have some prior experience with statmech
I would recommend this course to students who are interested in computational chemical research.
